speaker: alex
text: Welcome back to Claude Code Mastery. I'm Alex, and today we're covering something every developer uses daily: Git. We'll explore how Claude Code supercharges your version control workflow.

speaker: jamie
text: I'm Jamie, and I have to admit, Git is something I use but don't always love. Remembering commands, writing good commit messages, dealing with merge conflicts. Can Claude really make this easier?

speaker: alex
text: Absolutely. By the end of this episode, you'll be using Claude to create perfect commits, generate pull requests, review code, and handle complex Git operations without memorizing commands.

speaker: jamie
text: Let's start with the basics. How does Claude help me understand what I've changed?
chapter: SEGMENT 1: GIT STATUS AND UNDERSTANDING YOUR CHANGES (4 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: You can ask Claude "what's my current Git status" or simply "what have I changed?" Claude will run git status and git diff for you and summarize the results in plain English.
chapter: SEGMENT 1: GIT STATUS AND UNDERSTANDING YOUR CHANGES (4 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: So I don't need to remember the commands?
chapter: SEGMENT 1: GIT STATUS AND UNDERSTANDING YOUR CHANGES (4 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: Right. Claude knows all the Git commands. You just describe what you want to know. "Show me what files I've modified." "What's the difference between my version and the last commit?" "Have I staged anything?"
chapter: SEGMENT 1: GIT STATUS AND UNDERSTANDING YOUR CHANGES (4 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: That's much more natural than remembering flags.
chapter: SEGMENT 1: GIT STATUS AND UNDERSTANDING YOUR CHANGES (4 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: And Claude's summaries are often clearer than raw Git output. Instead of a wall of diff text, Claude might say "You've modified the user authentication in login.ts and added a new helper function in utils.ts."
chapter: SEGMENT 1: GIT STATUS AND UNDERSTANDING YOUR CHANGES (4 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: Human-readable summaries. Nice.
chapter: SEGMENT 1: GIT STATUS AND UNDERSTANDING YOUR CHANGES (4 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: What about actually creating commits? That's where I struggle with writing good messages.
chapter: SEGMENT 2: CREATING COMMITS WITH CLAUDE (5 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: This is one of my favorite Claude Code features. You can say "commit my changes" and Claude will analyze your modifications and propose an appropriate commit message.
chapter: SEGMENT 2: CREATING COMMITS WITH CLAUDE (5 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: It writes the message for me?
chapter: SEGMENT 2: CREATING COMMITS WITH CLAUDE (5 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: It proposes one. You can accept it, modify it, or ask for alternatives. Claude looks at what actually changed in the code, not just the file names, to write something meaningful.
chapter: SEGMENT 2: CREATING COMMITS WITH CLAUDE (5 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: So it's not just "updated files" or "fixed stuff"?
chapter: SEGMENT 2: CREATING COMMITS WITH CLAUDE (5 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: Definitely not. Claude will write something like "Add email validation to user registration form" or "Fix race condition in websocket connection handling." Specific, descriptive messages that capture the actual change.
chapter: SEGMENT 2: CREATING COMMITS WITH CLAUDE (5 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: What about the commit message format? Some projects have conventions.
chapter: SEGMENT 2: CREATING COMMITS WITH CLAUDE (5 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: Claude can adapt. Tell it "we use conventional commits" and it will format messages like "feat: add email validation" or "fix: resolve race condition." It knows popular conventions.
chapter: SEGMENT 2: CREATING COMMITS WITH CLAUDE (5 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: Can it handle longer commit messages with body text?
chapter: SEGMENT 2: CREATING COMMITS WITH CLAUDE (5 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: Yes. For complex changes, Claude will create a subject line plus a body that explains the why and how. "Refactor database connection pooling. The previous implementation could exhaust connections under high load. This change introduces a queue system."
chapter: SEGMENT 2: CREATING COMMITS WITH CLAUDE (5 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: I've heard about slash commit. What's that?
chapter: SEGMENT 3: THE SLASH COMMIT COMMAND (4 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: Slash commit is a quick shortcut that triggers Claude to create a commit. It's equivalent to saying "commit my staged changes with a good message." Very handy for quick commits.
chapter: SEGMENT 3: THE SLASH COMMIT COMMAND (4 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: Does it automatically stage files?
chapter: SEGMENT 3: THE SLASH COMMIT COMMAND (4 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: It can stage and commit together if you ask. "Stage and commit all my changes" or "commit everything including untracked files." Claude will handle the staging before committing.
chapter: SEGMENT 3: THE SLASH COMMIT COMMAND (4 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: What if I only want to commit some files?
chapter: SEGMENT 3: THE SLASH COMMIT COMMAND (4 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: Be specific. "Commit only the changes to auth.ts" or "stage the test files and commit them separately." Claude will create targeted commits for exactly what you specify.
chapter: SEGMENT 3: THE SLASH COMMIT COMMAND (4 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: Granular commits are good practice anyway.
chapter: SEGMENT 3: THE SLASH COMMIT COMMAND (4 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: They are. They make code review easier and make it simpler to revert specific changes if needed.
chapter: SEGMENT 3: THE SLASH COMMIT COMMAND (4 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: What about working with branches?

speaker: alex
text: Claude can help with all branch operations. "Create a new branch called feature-user-profile" or "switch to the development branch" or "show me all branches."

speaker: jamie
text: Can it help me name branches well?

speaker: alex
text: Yes! If you describe what you're working on, Claude can suggest a good branch name. "I'm adding dark mode support, what should I call the branch?" Claude might suggest "feature/dark-mode" or "add-dark-theme" depending on your project's naming conventions.

speaker: jamie
text: Does it detect existing conventions?

speaker: alex
text: It tries. If your existing branches use prefixes like "feature/" or "bugfix/", Claude will follow that pattern.

speaker: jamie
text: What about deleting old branches?

speaker: alex
text: "Delete the old feature-x branch" or "clean up my merged branches." Claude can help you tidy up. It will be careful to warn you before deleting anything not fully merged.

speaker: jamie
text: Now for the big one: pull requests. Can Claude help create PRs?

speaker: alex
text: This is incredibly powerful. You can say "create a pull request" and Claude will generate a PR with a title, description, and proper formatting.

speaker: jamie
text: It uses the GitHub CLI under the hood?

speaker: alex
text: Yes, Claude uses the gh command-line tool for GitHub operations. It can also work with GitLab and other platforms if you have the appropriate CLI tools set up.

speaker: jamie
text: What goes into the PR description?

speaker: alex
text: Claude analyzes all the commits being included in the PR and synthesizes a summary. It describes what changed, why it changed, and often includes a section for testing notes.

speaker: jamie
text: Does it look at individual commits or the overall diff?

speaker: alex
text: Both. It looks at each commit message for context, but also the actual code changes. If your commits are messy but the final code is clean, the PR description will focus on the end result.

speaker: jamie
text: What if I want to customize the description?

speaker: alex
text: You can guide Claude. "Create a PR, make sure to mention the performance improvement" or "create a PR with a section about database changes." Claude will incorporate your requirements.

speaker: jamie
text: Can Claude help me review other people's code?

speaker: alex
text: Yes! You can point Claude at a PR and ask for a review. "Review pull request 123" and Claude will fetch the changes and give you feedback.

speaker: jamie
text: What kind of feedback does it give?

speaker: alex
text: It varies based on the changes. Claude might highlight potential bugs, suggest better approaches, note missing error handling, or praise well-structured code. It's like having a thorough code reviewer.

speaker: jamie
text: Does it catch subtle issues?

speaker: alex
text: Often, yes. Claude can spot things like unused variables, inconsistent naming, potential null pointer issues, or logic that might fail edge cases. It's not perfect, but it catches a lot.

speaker: jamie
text: Can it leave comments on the PR directly?

speaker: alex
text: Not automatically. Claude will show you the feedback, and you can then add those comments yourself. This keeps you in control of what actually gets posted.

speaker: jamie
text: That's probably wise. Don't want AI comments flooding PRs.

speaker: alex
text: Right. Claude assists your review process. You make the final call on what feedback to share.

speaker: jamie
text: Let's talk about the scary one: merge conflicts.

speaker: alex
text: Merge conflicts don't have to be scary. Claude can help you understand what's conflicting and resolve it sensibly.

speaker: jamie
text: Walk me through a typical scenario.

speaker: alex
text: You try to merge or rebase, and Git says there are conflicts. You ask Claude "help me resolve the merge conflicts." Claude will show you each conflicted file and explain what's happening.

speaker: jamie
text: It explains the conflict?

speaker: alex
text: Yes. "In auth.ts, the main branch added rate limiting while your branch added logging. Both changed the same function." Now you understand why there's a conflict.

speaker: jamie
text: And then it suggests a resolution?

speaker: alex
text: Claude will propose a merged version that incorporates both changes if possible. Or it will ask you which version you prefer if they're truly incompatible.

speaker: jamie
text: Can it just fix them automatically?

speaker: alex
text: It can propose fixes, but you should review them. Merge conflicts often require human judgment about which behavior is correct. Claude helps you understand and suggests solutions.

speaker: jamie
text: Better than staring at conflict markers trying to figure out what happened.

speaker: alex
text: Much better. The context Claude provides is invaluable when you're trying to merge someone else's changes.

speaker: jamie
text: What about more advanced Git operations like rebasing?
chapter: SEGMENT 8: INTERACTIVE REBASE AND HISTORY (4 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: Claude can help with rebasing, though interactive rebase requires some care. You might say "rebase my branch onto main" and Claude will run the appropriate command.
chapter: SEGMENT 8: INTERACTIVE REBASE AND HISTORY (4 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: What if I want to squash commits?
chapter: SEGMENT 8: INTERACTIVE REBASE AND HISTORY (4 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: "Squash my last three commits into one" or "clean up my commit history before merging." Claude can guide you through squashing. It will often suggest a new combined commit message.
chapter: SEGMENT 8: INTERACTIVE REBASE AND HISTORY (4 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: What about amending commits?
chapter: SEGMENT 8: INTERACTIVE REBASE AND HISTORY (4 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: "Amend my last commit to include this file" or "update the last commit message." Claude handles these common scenarios. Just be careful with commits you've already pushed.
chapter: SEGMENT 8: INTERACTIVE REBASE AND HISTORY (4 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: Right, rewriting history that others have pulled is dangerous.
chapter: SEGMENT 8: INTERACTIVE REBASE AND HISTORY (4 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: Claude knows this too. If you try to amend a pushed commit, Claude will warn you about the implications.
chapter: SEGMENT 8: INTERACTIVE REBASE AND HISTORY (4 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: Sometimes I need to understand what happened in the past. Can Claude help with git log?
chapter: SEGMENT 9: VIEWING HISTORY AND LOGS (4 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: Absolutely. "Show me the recent commits" or "what changed in the last week" or "who modified this file recently." Claude will query the git history and present it clearly.
chapter: SEGMENT 9: VIEWING HISTORY AND LOGS (4 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: Can it find specific commits?
chapter: SEGMENT 9: VIEWING HISTORY AND LOGS (4 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: Yes. "Find the commit that added the payment feature" or "when did we change the API rate limit." Claude will search commit messages and show you the relevant commits.
chapter: SEGMENT 9: VIEWING HISTORY AND LOGS (4 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: What about git blame?
chapter: SEGMENT 9: VIEWING HISTORY AND LOGS (4 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: "Who wrote this function" or "when was this line added." Claude can run git blame and explain the results. It's great for understanding code ownership and history.
chapter: SEGMENT 9: VIEWING HISTORY AND LOGS (4 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: Are there dangerous Git commands Claude will protect me from?
chapter: SEGMENT 10: GIT SAFETY AND BEST PRACTICES (4 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: Yes. Claude is cautious about destructive operations. Force pushes, hard resets, history rewrites on shared branches. Claude will warn you and confirm before running these.
chapter: SEGMENT 10: GIT SAFETY AND BEST PRACTICES (4 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: What if I really need to force push?
chapter: SEGMENT 10: GIT SAFETY AND BEST PRACTICES (4 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: You can, but Claude will make sure you understand the implications. It won't force push to main or master without serious confirmation.
chapter: SEGMENT 10: GIT SAFETY AND BEST PRACTICES (4 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: Good guardrails.
chapter: SEGMENT 10: GIT SAFETY AND BEST PRACTICES (4 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: And Claude won't skip Git hooks or bypass verification unless you explicitly request it. It respects your project's workflow configuration.
chapter: SEGMENT 10: GIT SAFETY AND BEST PRACTICES (4 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: How does Claude fit into a typical development workflow?

speaker: alex
text: Here's my workflow. I start work on a branch. As I code, I periodically ask Claude "what have I changed." When a logical chunk is complete, "commit these changes." When the feature is done, "create a PR."

speaker: jamie
text: So Claude is there at each Git touchpoint.

speaker: alex
text: Exactly. And for reviewing others' work, I'll ask Claude to review the PR before I look at it myself. Claude's feedback primes my thinking.

speaker: jamie
text: Does this work with CI/CD pipelines?

speaker: alex
text: Claude doesn't directly interact with CI/CD, but it can help you understand pipeline results. "The build failed, what went wrong?" Claude can analyze error logs and help you fix issues.

speaker: jamie
text: What are your top tips for using Claude with Git?
chapter: SEGMENT 12: TIPS FOR GIT MASTERY (4 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: First, commit early and often. Small commits are easier to manage, and Claude writes better messages for focused changes.
chapter: SEGMENT 12: TIPS FOR GIT MASTERY (4 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: Atomic commits.
chapter: SEGMENT 12: TIPS FOR GIT MASTERY (4 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: Second, let Claude write the first draft of commit messages and PR descriptions. Then edit as needed. It's faster than starting from scratch.
chapter: SEGMENT 12: TIPS FOR GIT MASTERY (4 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: AI first draft, human polish.
chapter: SEGMENT 12: TIPS FOR GIT MASTERY (4 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: Third, use Claude to understand before you act. "What would happen if I rebased onto main?" is a valid question. Claude can explain the implications.
chapter: SEGMENT 12: TIPS FOR GIT MASTERY (4 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: Preview before execute.
chapter: SEGMENT 12: TIPS FOR GIT MASTERY (4 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: And fourth, don't be afraid to ask about Git concepts. "What's the difference between merge and rebase?" Claude can explain Git fundamentals whenever you need a refresher.
